You're totally right‚Äîit really is a juggling act! üòÑ I feel like I'm holding a bouquet in one hand and a to-do list in the other, trying not to drop either. And thank you! The venue was a big one to check off the list, so that gave me a nice little boost. üí™
As for the late-night thoughts... they‚Äôre annoying more than anything. It usually takes me about 30 minutes to an hour to fall asleep when my mind's spinning. Most days I‚Äôm fine, but if I had a really restless night (especially one filled with ‚Äúwhat-if‚Äù spirals about seating charts or speeches üò¨), then I wake up feeling kind of meh. Not exhausted, just... not refreshed, if that makes sense?
I‚Äôve been thinking about setting a ‚Äúcut-off‚Äù time for planning stuff‚Äîlike, no wedding talk or emails after 8 PM. Maybe even trying some light yoga or a warm drink before bed. I haven‚Äôt been super consistent with that yet, but it sounds doable, right?
Do you have any nighttime routines or tricks for calming your brain when it‚Äôs doing the most at the worst times? üòÖ
output_message:
Your plan to set a cut-off time for planning and incorporating light yoga sounds like a great way to wind down. It‚Äôs all about finding that balance, isn't it? üòä As for calming the mind, many people find that reading or listening to soothing music helps. Sometimes even writing down those spinning thoughts can be a way to let them go for the night.
